title: Sri Lanka’s CPC loses up to 1 billion rupees daily amid rupee fall
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT  – Sri Lanka’s Ceylon Petroleum Corporation is losing between 800 to 1000 billion rupees a day Chairman Sumith Wijesinghe said as oil prices rose and the rupee fell.
CPC is losing 110 rupees per litre of diesel sold and 52 rupees for a litre of petrol, he said.
“The daily loss is between 800 to 1000 million rupees,” Wijesinghe told reporters in Colombo.
CPC is selling Petrol at 254 rupees and a litre and auto diesel at 176 rupees a litre.
There were no plans to raise prices at the moment, Wijesinghe said.
Sri Lanka’s second fuel distributor Lanka IOC raised diesel to 214 rupees on March 10  and petrol to 303 rupees on March 24.
Sri Lanka’s fell steeply from 203 to around 330 over March as an attempt was made to float the rupee with a surrender requirement which pushed the rupee down and also a low policy rate.

There have been calls to change the central bank law to make it more difficult for central bankers to print money or turn it onto a currency board so that trade focused economists in the country (Mercantilsits) cannot depreciate the currency for short term trade gains and create social unrest.
Global oil prices have also moved up amid US money printing and a war in Ukraine. (Colombo/Apr11/2022)
